comments.author: Martin
comments.content: I almost never deep fry anything because I feel bad about all the oil that goes to waste (or to waist). What to do if your next fried meal is a month away? What's the best way to store (filtered) oil? And once you can't use it any more, how do you discard it safely?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Hey Martin - yeah, that can be an issue for me as well. You can put it through a coffee filter and then store it in the refrigerator, but I agree, a month can be a long time to store it. Another option, since you've probably only fried a little bit in it, is just to use it up over the next few weeks as your regular oil that you are going to saute in, grease pans, etc. Just taste it first to make sure it didn't acquire too strong a flavor.

comments.author: Bianca
comments.content: Great recipe! Pakoras are always my favourite to eat when dining out at an Indian restaurant. When making them home I like to use coconut oil; its high smoke point and health benefits are a great addition to any dish!

comments.author: Tofu Mom (Marti)
comments.content:
My kids LOVE pakoras,- and I love making pakoras but, for whatever reason, have never made onion ones.
We made these this afternoon. I didn't have any cumin (I KNOW! How is that possible?) so I subbed coriander. Which seemed like it worked very well. These were delicious. Completely!

comments.author: Isaac
comments.content: These look great. I made a version using onion, fresh fennel and basil leaves and served them with a beetroot balsamic puree, and decorated the plate with a few salad leaves.  Made a simple, but elegant starter

comments.author: Isaac
comments.content:
Actually, I hadn't read the recipe but I'm curious about your use of water. Most pakora recipes begin by mixing the sliced onions with a generous amount of salt which, after about 15 mins, draws out the water from the onion, then flour is mixed in to obtain the correct consistency, but no other liquid be that either water or oil, is added. 

Does your method have any advantage(s) over the more traditional one?

comments.author: Anubhav Rohatgi
comments.content:
Grate some ginger in the batter for added flavour. Put it the pakoras between two slides of white bread or buns with a spicy coriander chutney.. enjoy.

--Anubhav
